content: Fixing tag: "Arithmetics" -> "Arithmetic"

I would gladly accept this puzzle but i find it far too easy for a community puzzle. I would transform it in a flash clash if i could. I created a topic here: https://www.codingame.com/forum/t/puzzle-moderation-question-change-puzzle-category/1534

I find it way easier than the lucky numbers puzzle ^^
Took me about… 1mn :)

The way you present the 4 example gives a very big hint ; unless it is wanted, maybe it would make it harder to present the d()s in a single line.

And I would have put in the test case / validator something like 100000000  --> 8224670422194237 :P

When I first looked at this one a while ago, I thought "How small does he mean?" So I scrolled down to your solution, and in just a glance I saw the whole solution. I waited until today to solve it because I had forgotten what the solution was and wanted to work it out for myself.

It's a neat trick. :-) 

As an aside, some of your submissions are using a very strange character for ≤... This puzzle had the ⩽ character in there instead, which looks very strange on my screen. I have replaced it and have voted to approve this puzzle.
Cool math riddle, although I found it tougher than what you make it sound like. Actually I wonder what your trick really is, cause my solution looks like a regular math formula.
Looks like a 10mn clash to me, what do you think?
Took me way too long to understand and pass that one. Explaining the sum for e.g. n=4 would go a long way towards making it clear.
OK, I’ll explain it.

Why not, the moderators can change the time and do what they want with my contributions. ;-)
In fact, if you know or find the trick, it’s a one-liner. If not…
I think that we can also change the clash in summing not only the divisors but a known power of them.
Think orthogonally.

It’s not a strange character, it’s the usual one (leqslant in LaTeX).
I re-edit it. ;-)
I can move it to clash of code if other people think it's too easy to be a community puzzle.
I think that it was a CoC before having being moved here.
20mn clashes moved here.
Yep, moreover, I can copy and paste the code which ruins the idea of the CoC.

Dunno what the current ratings for clashes are, but per my rule-of-thumb classification, it's only flash if it's a simple "implement and submit". This one needs a transverse insight, give it more time.
Do clashes still distinguish between 5 and 10 minutes? (10' is perfect)

Okay, so now I'm curious. What's your rationale? It looks like it's mostly a locale-based thing?? I tend to use \leq since that's what most of CG uses.

The example when I click on "Click here for further instructions..." in the CREATE A PUZZLE shows ≤ in my browser. It's also the character used in The Descent, and other original CG puzzles.

At least that's the way the rest of the site looks to me. Does it look different for you? Is this a translation thing?
That’s the symbol I always see and use here.

So then that character must be "translated" based on locale, but it's left unchanged in the community puzzles.

I could be pedantic and say that you should use English-style symbols since all community puzzles are in English, but I guess it's not that important. Go ahead use your strange characters, crazy Frenchman. ;-)
It’s not strange, it a more beautiful character and it’s exactly the one I use when I write maths. ;-)

> I could be pedantic and say that you should use English-style symbols since all community puzzles are in English

Are they really? I see some of them in French. (first two in the list are Number of Exchanges by Delgan and Parenthesized Expressions by Plopx) (actually not sure about the titles in English)

I'm still not quite sure how the whole thing is supposed to be handled: some of them are bilingual in the staging area and they do look a bit messy.

I believe that is because those puzzles were originally accepted by CG staff, not by the current moderated process. Originally, the CG staff was verifying and then translating all the community puzzles.

Now, the verification and acceptance is handled by the community, and so translation is no longer done. You may notice that the translated ones don't say at the top who approved the puzzle, while the more recent additions list the moderators who voted to approve the puzzle.

I've tried it: it took me less than 2 minutes to do it (I used a chronometer).

I've defined a function that returns the sum of the divisors (just a for loop and a modulo) and I call this function for all the values in 1..n and sum the returned values.

OK, brute force? My values of n are not big enough.
There should be a fastest code mode too. ;-)
Oh, interesting, I forgot to test the last ones. The brute force is enough for test 4 but not the last validator (which is a problem, people won't understand why they don't have 100%).

I think that they will understand that their code is not fast enough and that the brute-force approach is O(n²), which is too slow.
I changed the last test-cases.
Ok, by adding a sqrt to find the divisors, it can be done in less than 10 minutes quite easily. We will wait for more votes before adding it.
MUCH better!
